user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Destroy:
```c
void UtList_Destroy(UtListHead_t *ListHead)
{
    uint32 i;

    for (i = 0; i < ListHead->NumberOfTags; ++i)
    {
        UtList_Reset(&ListHead->Tags[i]);
    }
    free(ListHead);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
UtList_Reset(&ListHead->Tags[i]);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The code fragment UtList_Reset(&ListHead->Tags[i]); does not itself call any functions from <string.h>, so it does not by itself violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. A violation could occur only if UtList_Reset internally uses string.h routines (e.g. memcpy/strcpy) and the pointer passed is out-of-bounds — for example if ListHead->NumberOfTags is larger than the actually allocated length of the Tags array (or the ListHead/Tags object is otherwise corrupted), so &ListHead->Tags[i] refers beyond the array and is then dereferenced by a string function. In the absence of such internal string.h usage or an out-of-bounds index, the fragment does not violate Rule 21.17.
